anchor.surface_text: Clause 19 provides various penalties for misconduct. The substance of these provisions is that an employee who is adjudged by the Company on examination of the employee and of facts to be guilty of misconduct is liable to be summarily dismissed without notice or compensation in lieu of notice or alternatively to be suspended for a period not exceeding fourteen days that the order of dismissal or suspension shall be in writing over the signature of an officer duly authorised for this purpose, and shall also briefly mention the reason on which it is based, and that no order for dismissal or suspension under this Standing Order shall be made unless the employee is informed in writing of the misconduct alleged against him and that he shall be given an opportunity to produce evidence in his defence.

concepts.interpretation: Court holds requires written charge, opportunity to defend, written order with reasons by authorised officer for dismissal/suspension on proof of misconduct; distinguishes from cl.20 discharge

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold, disagreeing with the High Court, and the Courts below that the order of discharge made by

holdings.text: The order made on January 16, 1958 was made under cl. 20 of the Standing Orders as an order of discharge on the ground that the employer had lost confidence in the employee, distinct from an order of dismissal or suspension under cl. 19.

anchor.surface_text: The only reasonable view to take of this order, in our opinion, is that this order was being made under cl. 20 on the ground that the employer had lost company- fidence in the employee and was in fact and in law an order of discharge as distinct from an order of dismissal or suspension.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of order: no mention of guilt of misconduct, references investigations and interview, states company cannot retain services; distinguishes cl.19 procedure from cl.20 general discharge right.

holdings.text: While the Resident Engineer may have found misconduct proved, he took a merciful view considering previous clean record and acted under cl. 20 instead of cl. 19.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that while the Resident Engineer who held the enquiry may, have been satisfied that an act of misconduct for which the employee was liable to dismissal had been proved he took a merciful view of has companyduct in view of his previous clean record, and proceeded accordingly to act under cl. 20 of the Standing Orders instead of proceeding under cl. 19.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inferred from context of enquiry, clean record, and choice of cl.20 despite possible misconduct.

holdings.text: The powers of the Company under cl. 19 to dismiss or suspend and under cl. 20 to discharge are both covered by cl. 10 of the power of attorney.

anchor.surface_text: The power of the Company under el. 19 of the Standing Orders to dismiss or suspend and its power under el. 20 to discharge an employee are both companyered by cl.10 of the power of attorney,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual matching: PoA cl.10 authorizes appoint, dismiss, suspend, terminate subject to Standing Orders, encompassing cl.19 penalties and cl.20 discharge.

holdings.text: Exercise of power under cl. 20 by the Resident Engineer under the power of attorney amounted in law to exercise by the Company itself.

anchor.surface_text: If there be numberhing in law to prevent these powers being delegated to the Resident Engineer there companyld be numberescape from the companyclusion that the exercise of the power cl. 20 in the present case by the Resident Engineer amounted in law to an exercise of the power by the Company itself,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agency principle: delegate acts as principal; no personal capacity but under PoA.

holdings.text: There is nothing in law which bars delegation of the Company's disciplinary powers under the Standing Orders to an officer.

anchor.surface_text: Is there anything in law which bars such delegation? We are unable to find any.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory or other legal prohibition found; company acts via officers per Articles, not shareholders.

holdings.text: No provision in Articles of Association bars delegation of disciplinary powers to officers.

anchor.surface_text: It is numberodys case that in the Articles of Association of the Jabalpur Electric Supply Co., there is anything barring the delegation of the disciplinary powers of the Company to any of its officers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit: nobody's case that AoA bars; companies delegate per business needs.

holdings.text: The words 'subject to the Standing Orders' in cl. 10 of PoA do not prevent delegation but ensure delegate does not exceed company's powers under Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can we see that the words subject to the Standing Orders from time to time given by the Company with which cl. 10 of the power of attorney opens affects the delegation. On a proper interpretation of these words their only effect is that in exercising the power to appoint, dismiss, suspend or terminate the services of the employees at Jabalpur the delegate cannot do anything beyond what the companypany itself can do under the Standing Orders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper interpretation: limits scope, does not negate delegation; no reasonable construction prohibits exercise.

holdings.text: The order of discharge by the Resident Engineer was in exercise of validly delegated power and there has been no breach of the Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold, disagreeing with the High Court, and the Courts below that the order of discharge made by the Resident Engineer was in exercise of the power validly delegated to him and that there, has been numberbreach of the Standing Orders by such action,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis: valid classification under cl.20, valid delegation via PoA covering cl.20, no legal bar, proper limits.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order passed by the High Court and direct that the appellants application under Art.
